body.p:
I am only this day enabled
to address you in reply to your inquiries
recd. some weeks ago.

I have just decided to leave
here in the steamship departing hence
for New York on the 26th proximo, and
on my arrival at New York shall
at once proceed with the remains
of an old friend to New Port, avoiding
all show and parade in New York.

I intend to have proper arrangements
made at New Port to convey the body
on its arrival, at once to the Synagogue
whence it will be removed to the Cemetery as soon as practicable.

I shall invite no one, or corporation
to take part in the funeral ceremo
nies, but the time and the simple manner above stated, will enable all who wish to follow the remains to their last
resting place. I do not wish it definitely
stated that the remains will come
on the same vessel with me, because
the agents of the vessel, fear that such
an announcement would prevent some
superstitious people from travelling by
the same conveyance on which there was a corpse—

The amount of the foregoing you
will please state in your next
(May
No) of the Occident, by authority
as this is intended as “the due notice
promised by the Executor to all who
wish to take part in the funeral ceremonies.

Under no circumstances will
we permit any public procession
in New York, and even in New Port
all that is done must be spontaneous.

Now on to the ceremonies—It is not improbable that the Congn. here may
request Mr. Gutheim to accompany
the remains &c, in which case the
Executors will prefer his performing
the last sad offices together with your-
-self or perhaps others and in that case I will advise
you in time to make any necessary
preparations. One thing I must impress
on you, and that is, that no speaker on
an occasion like this will be, should
exceed 20 minutes in his address. As
to the Hakafoth, if performed at all they
ought to be read, and not opera-ised
as is usually done.

At New Port the several delegations
attending, will take any place they
please in the funeral train. I will
not take any responsibility in working

out their stations—there will be no
pall bearers—no tomfoolery—no delay
on the score of etiquette to the living—
a plain unostentatious Jewish funeral
at which any and all can attend accord
ing to the laws & republican custom
of Jews—

I regret to find that your education
al Society has not taken the steps
recommended in the Circular of the
Executors, by which it seems likely
that your Institution will not get
paid the 20,000, at least before the next
year; and not even then unless you
legally appoint some person here
to represent that corporation. If
the officers object to appointing my
brother Maudes? they can send the power
of atty & other requisite papers to any
one else. The object of the Executor in
sending out the Circular, was simply
to save cost of commissions to the
Societies, and as we are responsible
for the acts of any one we recommend,
we naturally selected a man in whose
integrity we had confidence. On one thing
you may rely—we shall only pay in one
way, and that is, through a legally authorised
agent here. This is entre nous. The law
gives the exr. 12 mos before paying anything, &

then we are the judges under the Law
and practice of our Courts, as to the
manner in which we shall take
voucher receipts ? to deposite
in court when asking for an appro
val of our stewardship—

Your Mr. Solis President has acknow
ledged recpt of our Circular and seems
to think that we are going to keep up
a general correspondence—giving all
particulars of our movements. His rights
are simple, our duties are plain, and
whilst we shall respect legally all that
is his due—we shall not make him
an exception, to the general course
that we have marked out to persue?
towards all.

In saying that we shall make at the funeral no distinction
you will not understand me on including the Ministry
the church is always to be respected and the ?
is not to be overlooked on any occasion when present.
Indeed I had better say at once, that I claim
the right to alter my present views & intentions,
in accordance with such circumstances as may
happen hereafter—

I may say to you that after much discussion
I have induced the Exr. To agree to pay off all the
Legacies that are properly claimed here, before I depart; to do which considerable sacrifices will
have to be made in raising Cash means—lent
no bequest will be paid unless to a legally authorised
person here representing the legatee, and when I
leave nothing will be done till next winter—
